steps.title: Let the cooked meatloaf cool completely before freezing it.
steps.content: Let the cooked meatloaf cool completely before freezing it. Make sure your leftovers or extra meatloaf is cool to the touch before storing it. This will help protect the meatloaf from freezer burn. [1] X Research source Freezing warm leftovers causes the steam from the heat to turn to ice and dry out your food.

steps.title: Cut leftover meatloaf into individual portions.
steps.content: Cut leftover meatloaf into individual portions. Cut your fully cooked meatloaf into slices the size of an individual portion. This will make it easier to reheat portions without drying them out. [2] X Research source Bake your go-to meatloaf recipe in muffin tins and freeze for single servings. Each meatloaf "muffin" will be about one serving size. Meatloaf will get dry if you reheat it for too long after it's already cooked. While it's perfectly safe to freeze and reheat an entire meatloaf, it will be more juicy and tender if you reheat individual portions.

steps.title: Wrap each portion in foil or plastic wrap and a plastic bag.
steps.content: Wrap each portion in foil or plastic wrap and a plastic bag. Wrap it tightly in a layer of foil or plastic wrap. Then, use a freezer-safe, zip-top plastic bag to make air-tight packages. [3] X Research source Wrapping the meatloaf helps protect other foods in your freezer from contamination.

steps.title: Save cooked meatloaf in the freezer for up to 3 months.
steps.content: Save cooked meatloaf in the freezer for up to 3 months. Cooked meat is best to eat up to 3 months after being frozen. After 3 months, you should throw away any uneaten leftovers. [4] X Trustworthy Source FoodSafety.gov Online portal combining food safety information from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, the Food Safety and Inspection Service, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Go to source Leftovers in the fridge should be eaten within 1-2 days.

steps.title: Defrost the portions you want to eat in the fridge overnight.
steps.content: Defrost the portions you want to eat in the fridge overnight. The night before you would like to eat your frozen meatloaf, take it out of the freezer and put it in the fridge. It will be ready to reheat the next day. [5] X Research source This is the safest and easiest way to defrost meatloaf. It also preserves the texture and moistness.

steps.title: Defrost portions in a cold water bath to thaw them more quickly.
steps.content: Defrost portions in a cold water bath to thaw them more quickly. If you forgot to take out a slice of meatloaf the night before, you can thaw out a portion more quickly in a cold water bath. Seal the slice in a zip-top bag and put it in a bowl of cold water. Change the water every 30 minutes to keep it cold. [6] X Research source Warm the slice in the oven once it has thawed.

steps.title: Reheat the portions in the oven at 350 °F (177 °C) for 20 minutes.
steps.content: Reheat the portions in the oven at 350 °F (177 °C) for 20 minutes. Preheat the oven first. Then bake the meatloaf 20-25 minutes. The exact amount of time will depend on how big your portions are. [7] X Research source Wrap each portion in foil to keep juices in, making your leftovers more moist.

steps.title: Mix and assemble the meatloaf according to your recipe.
steps.content: Mix and assemble the meatloaf according to your recipe. Mix all of the ingredients together according to your specific recipe. Assemble it in the loaf pan, and shape it the way you want. Don't bake the meatloaf at all. [8] X Research source If you want to make the meatloaf the next day, you can put it in the fridge at this point.

steps.title: Cover and freeze the meatloaf in the pan for 24 hours.
steps.content: Cover and freeze the meatloaf in the pan for 24 hours. Cover the assembled meatloaf with plastic wrap or foil. Place the pan in the freezer for 1 day. [9] X Research source Meat with a higher fat content will be easier to take out of the frozen pan, since the grease will help it slide out. If you are using ground beef in your recipe, look for 85% lean.

steps.title: Remove the frozen loaf, wrap it in foil, and put it in a plastic bag.
steps.content: Remove the frozen loaf, wrap it in foil, and put it in a plastic bag. After about a day, take the frozen meatloaf out of the pan. Wrap it tightly in foil or plastic wrap. Use a plastic freezer bag to be sure the meatloaf is in a completely airtight package. [10] X Research source This step helps better protect the meat and also frees up your loaf pan.

steps.title: Store meatloaf in the freezer for up to 3 months.
steps.content: Store meatloaf in the freezer for up to 3 months. Like cooked meat, raw ground meat is safe to eat up to 3 months after being frozen. If your meatloaf has been frozen for longer, throw it out. [11] X Trustworthy Source FoodSafety.gov Online portal combining food safety information from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, the Food Safety and Inspection Service, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Go to source Meatloaf with freezer burn is safe to eat, as long as it has been frozen for less than 3 months. It will be more dry than meatloaf without freezer burn, but the taste will be the same.

steps.title: Thaw the meat in the fridge overnight.
steps.content: Thaw the meat in the fridge overnight. The night before you are ready to cook your meatloaf, put it in the fridge. The next day, it will be thawed enough to cook. [12] X Research source Be sure your meatloaf is still tightly wrapped to prevent the raw meat from contaminating anything else in your fridge.

steps.title: Thaw the meatloaf in the oven if you didn't defrost it overnight.
steps.content: Thaw the meatloaf in the oven if you didn't defrost it overnight. Place the frozen meatloaf in the oven first, and then set the temperature to 350 °F (177 °C). Cook the meatloaf for 1 1/2-1 3/4 hours. [13] X Research source The meatloaf will thaw while the oven is preheating. Depending on how frozen your meatloaf was, it might take a little bit longer to cook completely.

steps.title: Cook the meatloaf in the pan at 350 °F (177 °C) for 1 1/4-1 1/2 hours.
steps.content: Cook the meatloaf in the pan at 350 °F (177 °C) for 1 1/4-1 1/2 hours. Put the meatloaf back into the pan. Preheat the oven first, then bake the meatloaf for 1 1/4-1 1/2 hours, or until a meat thermometer reads 160 °F (71 °C). [14] X Research source To get an accurate reading from a meat thermometer, stick it into the center of the meatloaf.
